body.p:
House of Reps
1st March 1861
My dear Govr.

I am not in the habit of often especially of asking the interposition of Executive Clemency as to a stay of criminal process. I am justified in doing so on the present occasion by the strong equity of the present application. Norman Sebree was fined some two years ago in the Boone Circuit Court for a raffle for some turkeys, which took place in his stable at Bellvue, he keeping tavern there at that time -- He admitted the fact as I learned on the trial but innocently believed that a raffle for four turkeys was not a violation of the criminal statutes agt gaming -- Several Circuit Judges & among them Judge H O Brown & Judge Reid had decided
on the same Circuit that playing games for segars or raffles for turkeys were not violations of the statute -- He was however for his ignorance fined two hundred dollars -- He was so clearly innocent of any mala fides that I understand Judge Nuttall -- the Comlt Attorney Mr Major the entire Grand & petit Jury who tried it all ask your Excellency to remit -- You stayed it -- & that stay is now about expiring -- I do not think a stronger case could well be presented.

Mr Sebree is a poor industrious man -- & to force him to pay this fine would be almost to break him up -- I do hope
as he had no intention to violate the law that you will pardon & remit the fine --

Boone Cir. Ct
$200 } Gaming
N. Sebree
